content: Wardle finished in fifth place, and Edmund in sixth. The first race at Brands was quite quiet compared to what followed, as Formula Ford became well-known for its rough-and-tumble antics. The most successful driver of the 1967 season was Dan Hawkes, who drove a Motor Racing Stables Type 51 to victory in five of the season's Formula Ford races. In late 1967 or early 1968, a slightly modified model called the 51A was offered to customers. The Lotus was different from the Elan in several ways. The dashboard was now fully equipped and boasted a polished mahogany facia, through-flow ventilation, and a two-waveband radio, while the door trims were full-depth and needed no elbow cutouts. The boot was also much larger than the two-seater Elan's. Later cars had a deeper boot due to a change from a transverse exhaust silencer to a longitudinal unit. As launched in September 1967, the +2 cost £1672 in component form or £1923 including purchase tax fully built, although by January of 1968 this had become £1718 and £2113 respectively. The standard +2 continued to be sold alongside the +2S well into 1970, and with chassis numbers for the two cars listed on Lotus records as one model, exact production numbers are not available.

Type 51 proved a popular choice. Indeed, the Type 51 was something of a sales success for the Lotus Components branch of the company, with a grand total of 218 cars being built (though some sources suggest 150 or 165 cars). This was despite strong competition from other manufacturers. 51B and 51C models were developed, primarily for sale in the USA. The 'B' featured updated and improved rear suspension with upper trailing links mounted to the top of the upright, while the 'C' models had a Hewland transaxle fitted. Some got the Mark 6, some the Mark 8.

One footnote to the Type 51 story is the curious 51R displayed at the January 1968 Racing Car Show. This was a novelty exercise, devised as a publicity stunt by then Lotus sales manager Graham Arnold which attempted to turn the Type 51 into a road car.

content:
One exception to the lack of development on the Type 41 during 1967 was the Type 41B entered by Lotus Components for Jackie Oliver. It has to be noted that this wasn’t actually for Formula 3; it was in fact entered in several Formula 2 races in 1967. Powered by the new FVA engine from Cosworth, the 41B designation was actually intended to be for the 1967 Formula B spec car for use in the USA with Lotus Twin-cam power, but with the Formula 2 car taking its name, the FB car would confusingly be called the 41C. Only a single 41B spaceframe chassis was officially built to compete in 1967, and the combination did achieve some reasonable results against the other much more sophisticated monocoque machinery.

Officially entered by Lotus Components, and usually alongside the two green and yellow Team Lotus Type 48 Formula 2 cars for Jim Clark and Graham Hill, the 41B would race in white and black livery at 14 championship and non-championship races in a grueling 1967 Formula 2 season. After missing the first two races of 1967 at Snetterton and Silverstone, the 41B made its debut.

Although the Type 41 Formula 3 chassis had been finding plenty of success in the USA and Canada, good results in the 1966 European races were getting harder to come by. With Team Lotus concentrating their efforts on Formula 1, the Formula 3 car was not receiving the factory support and development that it needed in order to keep the customer cars up front in 1967. content:
For the 1968 Formula 3 season, Lotus again rolled out the successful spaceframe Type 41, this time with a new interesting wedge profile and revised front suspension taken from the Type 47 racing version of the Europa. It featured unequal length wide-based wishbones with outboard coil-spring/damper units and an anti-roll bar. The rear suspension, brakes, and gearbox all remained the same as on the 1966-67 versions of the car, with the wishbones, top links, and radius arms mounted on adjustable spherical bearings, outboard coil-spring/damper units, and an adjustable anti-roll bar. Officially titled the 41X in the 1968 Gold Leaf Team Lotus press releases, this car was intended as a test-bed for a new Formula 3 car for the 1969 season, which was to be designated the Type 55. This car was never actually built, though, and thus a permanent gap was left in the Lotus Type number sequence.

The 1968 Formula 1 season would be the one that spawned the ‘high wing’ concept of aerodynamics, and Team Lotus was quick in carrying this over to their lower formulae cars such as the 41X and the later Type 70. Starting the season in the F3 support race to the International Trophy.

content: The Formula 1 season would be the one that spawned the 'high wing' concept of aerodynamics, and Team Lotus was quick in carrying this over to their lower formulae cars such as the 41X and the later Type 70. Starting the season in the F3 support race to the International Trophy at Silverstone, John Miles won easily in the plain red car, which had no aero appendages. By the time the season got into full swing, the car was seen running in the controversial new Gold Leaf Team Lotus colours, and with an adjustable high wing at the back, balanced out by front wings (without endplates) on the front of the low, wide, almost pointed nose. At some of the early races, the team ran an upswept rear body section that completed the sleek wedge shape reminiscent of both the 1968 Type 49B Formula 1 car and the Type 56 Indianapolis car. However, when the team changed from a single down-draught Weber carburettor to a twin set-up, along with the high wing configuration, the engine cover that covered the 1000cc Holbay power-unit, which was inclined 30-degrees to the vertical, was discarded completely.

However, when the team changed from a single down-draught Weber carburettor to a twin set-up, along with the high wing configuration, the engine cover that covered the 1000cc Holbay power-unit that was inclined 30-degrees to the vertical, was discarded completely. The 115bhp engine put its power to the road through a single dry-plate 7.24-inch diaphragm clutch and a Hewland MkIV 4-speed gearbox. Wheels were 13-inch Lotus magnesium knock-on, 4-spoke with 7-inch front rims and 9-inch at the rear. With John Miles driving the one-off Type 41X over the course of the season (seen above at Brands Hatch) in just ten races, the car produced four major victories, several second-place finishes, and a string of lap records. By the final race of the year at Brands Hatch in December, however, it was apparent that the Type 41 was falling off the pace of the Brabham, Tecno, and even Merlyn chassis that had been winning the majority of the races, and was nearing the end of its useful life. Thus, the Type 55 concept was shelved and a totally new design, the Type 59, was pushed through for use in Formula 3.
